Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wintertime INvestigation of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund the deployment of a research aircraft in a study to observe wintertime pollution in the Northeastern United States. While there have been a number of studies that have sampled atmospheric chemistry in the warm season, there have been relatively few studies in the cool season and none with the advanced instrumentation that the scientific community now possesses. This is important because the processes that affect how much pollution is created and how far it travels depends significantly on water vapor and sunlight, both of which are dramatically different in summer and winter. This study will examine how these processes work in cold temperatures and low sunlight and provide input to numerical modelers to help improve forecasts and provide guidance for policymakers on how to best reduce harmful air pollution events.

The Wintertime Investigations of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER) project will take place in early 2015. The main goal is to provide observations needed to develop a deeper understanding of the chemical and physical processes which govern the spatial distribution of anthropogenic pollutants during winter. The researchers argue that a majority of observations in polluted mid-latitude regions have been in summer, when plentiful sunlight and water vapor lead to the rapid oxidation of NOx and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by OH. In the winter months when OH concentrations are much lower and temperatures are colder, different oxidation pathways are expected to be more important. This leads to the slower oxidation of reactive pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, VOCs and sulfur dioxide, resulting in longer atmospheric lifetimes and therefore the transport of these species over wider geographic areas. The colder winter temperatures also change the equilibrium gas-particle partitioning of semi-volatile species (e.g. HNO3) favoring the formation of particles and resulting in seasonal changes in dominant aerosol components. For example, studies have shown that inorganic nitrogen is a much higher component of the aerosol in the winter. The three primary research objectives are: 1) Characterize the chemical transformations of wintertime emissions via multiphase, nocturnal, and photochemical processes, 2) Assess the dominant mechanisms of secondary aerosol formation and quantify the geographical distribution of inorganic and organic aerosol types during winter, and 3) Constrain wintertime emission inventories of key pollutants for urban areas, power plants, and agricultural areas, and characterize their export over the North Atlantic. In addition to the broader impacts stated above, a significant number of students would be involved in the field campaign and data analysis activities. Outreach activities will include a media day, visits by K-12 students, and project updates through social media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported measurements of aerosol chemical species from the NSF-C130 research aircraft operating over the Northeastern US during the winter season (the so-called WINTER study). The goals were to support the overall scientific objectives of the WINTER study and to specifically investigate: 1) The acidity (pH) of fine ambient particles and its impacts; 2) the extent of biomass burning influence on fine particle aerosol concentrations. Both research questions are related to understanding sources and processes that contribute to fine particle mass and processes that generally affect air quality in a cold season.

An overall broad result of this research has been the wider recognition of the extreme acidity of fine particles and the importance of aerosol pH in modulating many aerosol processes.

In all locations investigated during the WINTER study, bulk fine particle (PM1) pH was very low, with particle pH ranging between ­0.5 and 2. pH predictions were validated by comparisons between predicted and observed gas­particle partitioning of semi volatile ammonia and nitric acid. Limitations in predicting pH due to model assumptions, such as aerosol liquid phase state, were also addressed. This project also supported studies of comparisons of the aerosol pH determined for WINTER to that of other study locations in the US. In contrast to the WINTER study findings, fine particle pH was about 1 pH unit lower in the southeastern US in summer (SOAS study), whereas in the Los Angeles basin the pH was slightly higher. (Publications: Guo et al., JGR 2016; Guo et al., ACP 2017).

Our investigation of pH moved further beyond the WINTER project to address issues raised by other investigators. A number of recent studies proposed processes that depended on pH, or affect pH, that we viewed as problematic. In response, through this funding, we published two papers addressing these issues. In the first paper we showed that a proposed new mechanism for generation of sulfate haze in China would likely not occur because the pH was much lower than the researchers had estimated and the mechanism’s reactions are very slow under acidic aerosol conditions. In the other case, we showed that a proposed organic film over particles that could reconcile discrepancies in observed and thermodynamic model-predicted aerosol ammonium to sulfate ratios could be addressed by simply including non-volatile cations in the thermodynamic analysis. (A secondary issue was with use of highly biased aerosol data sets). (Publications: Guo et al., Scientific Reports, 2017; Guo et al., ACP, 2018, in review).

We also applied our knowledge on pH to practical problems. In the first case we performed additional ground-based measurements to investigate the pH of particles as a function of particle size. Consistent with the PM1 bulk analysis, fine particles had low pH, but the pH transitioned to near neutral as size increased beyond 1µm. Through these size resolved measurements we showed that low pH of PM1 dissolves transition metals emitted in insoluble forms (metal oxides) producing metal ions that are highly reactive and known to be toxic, thereby linking sulfate and acidity to adverse health outcomes. (Publication: Fang et al., ES&T, 2017).

In the second study the issue of nitrogen oxides (NOx) versus ammonia (NH3) control as a way to reduce PM2.5 mass in regions where ammonium nitrate is a large fraction of fine particle mass was assessed. We focused on a case study in northeastern Europe, but extend the analysis to other regions around the globe. We report that a critical ambient particle pH of 3 separates the regimes of effective NOx versus NH3 control. This has significant regulatory implications. (Publication: Guo et al., ACP, 2018).

As for the other major objective relating to biomass burning to PM mass levels in the northeast, we compared the standard biomass burning tracer, levoglucosan, measured directly in a particle liquid extract, to the aerosol mass spectrometer ­derived biomass burning tracer. We showed that the liquid-based system produces a more chemically specific burning tracer.  This can lead to large discrepancies in predicted overall biomass burning impacts in the WINTER data set. Estimates of source impacts with the liquid-measured levoglucosan suggest large contributions to fine particle organic carbon for the WINTER study. These results are also being compared to model predictions of biomass burning impacts. (Publication: Sullivan et al., JGR 2018 in review).

Overall, this research has advanced the characterization of fine particle acidity (pH) and its impacts, ranging from effects on ambient aerosol concentrations and how to reduce aerosol concentrations, to the effects of pH on aerosol toxicity and health. Measurements and assessment of biomass burning tracers were also used to estimate the contribution of residential burning to the overall aerosol mass concentration over the northeastern US in winter.  This project supported one graduate student and comprised a major portion of his PhD thesis (graduated Aug. 2017), and supported a mid­career female research scientist.
